unit_learning_outcomes.description: Formulate a research question that will contribute to new knowledge/insights within your research field.
Develop and apply a theoretical model to the research project.
Situate individual research projects within its broader research context, reviewing associated issues, debates and methodologies.
Communicate research plans, approaches, outcomes, and budget outlines in written and other forms.
Undertake a qualitative or quantitative analysis of the data collected, inclusive of critical reasoning and argumentation.
Present a conclusion to the project with reference to how the project and its findings contribute to enhancing existing literature within the field.
Make strategic decisions about how to approach individual research problems.
Research and conduct a comprehensive and critical literature review in a specific research area.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: You are expected to conduct independent research during the year, such as locating, reading and analysing prescribed and additional relevant materials, collecting and analysing data and producing written work at various stages, as determined by the supervisors. The time spent on this is reflected across the assessment tasks.

assessments.description: In accordance with international convention, you will ‘defend’ your thesis via an oral presentation and respond to questioning in a Completion Symposium. Faculty members will attend and assess the completion talks. The format for this presentation will be a 15 min talk with 5 min of questions from the audience and chairperson. This may be delivered online should it not be able to be delivered on campus.

You will work with your supervisor to produce a detailed research plan. This could incorporate the research plan submitted at the time of application and developed through further consultation with your supervisor. The plan should outline a 10-months project plan, approximately 2500 -3000 words in length, describing the scope and objectives of the MRes research project. The proposal should include: a rationale for the research question/ hypothesis; methodology; experimental plan; budget; ethical requirement (as appropriate – see other information); and timeline. Satisfactory completion of this task is required to confirm your candidature as an MRes student.

You are expected to complete a significant individual research project in order to demonstrate individual research capability to conduct a PhD research project. You will prepare a written thesis according to Departmental guidelines, which will be externally examined by a University approved examination panel. As a guide, the thesis will have a structured format (i.e.: Introduction, Aims, Methods, Results, Discussion and Conclusion sections).

You will receive an Outcome Letter from OHDRTP once both of the examiners reports have been received. If corrections are required, you will have 14 days to submit a corrections report to OHDRTP. Once corrections have been reviewed and approved by the Thesis Examination Sub-Committee (TESC), you will be invited to submit your final thesis within 14 days of the notification. If corrections are not required, you will be invited to submit your final thesis within 14 days of the dated Outcome Letter.
